Sentence: China launched Big Fund III with 344 billion yuan (~US$47.5 billion) to boost domestic semiconductor production and equipment.
China was forecast to invest about US$38 billion in new chipmaking equipment, leading the world despite a slowdown.
China Unicom opened a $390 million data centre in Xining using mostly domestic AI chips.
SMIC trialed its first domestically produced DUV lithography machine to push toward 7 nm production.
Beijing subsidised purchases of domestic AI chips, aiming for self-reliance in smart computing infrastructure by 2027.
Big Fund III managers targeted lithography, EDA tools, and manufacturing equipment to close critical gaps.
Big Fund III managers targeted lithography, EDA tools, and manufacturing equipment to close critical gaps.
Big Fund III managers targeted lithography, EDA tools, and manufacturing equipment to close critical gaps.
SiCarrier unveiled new domestic chipmaking tools, including etching and deposition equipment.
China expanded investments in memory (DRAM, NAND), SiC, and advanced packaging, despite export controls.
SMIC (Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corporation) was supported by Big Fund III.
Hua Hong Semiconductor was supported by Big Fund III.
Yangtze Memory Technologies (YMTC) was supported by Big Fund III.

Action: is expected to be supported by
Sentence: Shanghai Micro Electronics Equipment (SMEE) is expected to be supported by Big Fund III.

Action: is likely to be supported by
Sentence: SMEE (Shanghai Micro Electronics Equipment) is likely to be supported by Big Fund III.

Action: is likely to be supported by
Sentence: Empyrean Technology is likely to be supported by Big Fund III.

Action: is intended to be supported by
Sentence: Huawei is intended to be supported by Big Fund III.

Action: is likely to be supported by
Sentence: Third-generation chip companies in Beijing is likely to be supported by Big Fund III.
Naura Technology Group likely benefited from China’s $38 billion equipment investment as a top domestic tool supplier.
AMEC likely benefited from China’s $38 billion equipment investment due to its leading etch and CVD tools.
SiCarrier likely benefited from China’s $38 billion equipment investment as a Huawei-linked domestic toolmaker.
Yuliangsheng likely benefited from China’s $38 billion equipment investment by supplying immersion DUV lithography machines under trial at SMIC.
SMIC purchased chipmaking equipment as part of China’s $38 billion investment, trialing domestic DUV tools.
ASML was constrained from selling advanced lithography tools to China under U.S.-aligned export controls despite China’s $38 billion equipment investment.
Tokyo Electron was constrained from selling advanced semiconductor tools to China under Japanese export controls despite China’s $38 billion equipment investment.
Applied Materials was constrained from selling advanced semiconductor equipment to China under U.S. export controls despite China’s $38 billion equipment investment.
Alibaba’s chip unit T-Head supplied about 72% of the AI chips used in China Unicom’s Xining data centre announcement
Beijing subsidised purchases of Huawei’s Ascend 910 chips under the domestic AI chip subsidy program on April 26, 2024
Beijing subsidised firms that purchase domestically produced GPUs for intelligent computing services under the April 2024 initiative
CXMT expanded its DRAM production capacity from ~70,000 wafers/month in 2022 to 120,000 in 2023.
CXMT developed newer DRAM and NAND products despite export controls.
YMTC substituted U.S.-sourced equipment with domestic alternatives after restrictions.
YMTC expanded NAND flash memory development with capital injection from state funds.
Tongfu Microelectronics expanded advanced packaging capacity, including HBM and CoWoS-like processes.
Tongfu Microelectronics developed packaging capabilities for high-performance computing chips.
KLA reported that China revenue would decline ~20% in 2025 versus 2024, with the China sales mix falling from ~40% to the high-20% range.
ASM International forecast lower China sales in 2025, noting China would represent only the low-to-high 20% range of total sales.
Lam Research warned that new U.S. export controls may inhibit its ability to sell into China despite maintaining overall guidance.
NVIDIA lost China GPU sales after new restrictions, with regulators banning major firms from buying its China-specific chips and the company excluding China from near-term forecasts.
Synopsys cut guidance after export restrictions derailed China sales in its Design IP business.
Nikon faced new export policy restrictions that could impact sales of semiconductor manufacturing equipment to China.
Nikon saw reduced reliance on China sales, pivoting to lower-spec tools not restricted by export bans.
Advantest reported a drop in China sales, with quarterly sales to China falling from ~45 billion yen to ~36 billion yen.
Advantest warned about risks from softening demand in China and the potential impact of export controls.
Synopsys lost market share to domestic EDA firms, as Big Fund III supported Empyrean and reduced China’s reliance on U.S. tools.
Micron Technology faced competition from Chinese NAND expansion, as YMTC scaled production with Big Fund support.

Target: Chinese industrial and automotive chip segments
Sentence: Texas Instruments was exposed to reduced demand from Chinese industrial/automotive chip segments as local firms gained state backing.
Intel was challenged by Chinese AI/GPU startups like Biren, which received backing from Big Fund III and reduced reliance on U.S. suppliers.

Target: China GPU sales to domestic alternatives
Sentence: NVIDIA lost China GPU sales to domestic alternatives, as Chinese firms developed AI chips with Big Fund III support and regulators restricted its market access.
Hongxin (HSMC / Wuhan Hongxin) failed to benefit from Big Fund III because its project collapsed due to funding shortfalls and lack of approvals.
Tsinghua Unigroup failed to benefit from Big Fund III as its DRAM and NAND projects collapsed amid debt and mismanagement before restructuring.
Innoscience struggled to benefit from Big Fund III due to high R&D costs, unprofitability, and intense price pressures despite policy support.
Intel was challenged by Chinese AI/GPU startups like Biren, which received backing from Big Fund III and reduced reliance on U.S. suppliers.
